title: How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
summary:
How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
Bring Me The NewsThe Twin Cities averages 54 inches of snow each winter, but 2019-20 appears to be on track to sprint past that annual average for a third consecutive winter.
That'll happen if the Twin Cities simply gets its average monthly snow totals the rest of the winter.
The average in February is 7.8 inches while March and April bring average snowfall totals of 10.2 inches and 2.5 inches, respectively.

title: It's the Cloudiest January Stretch in Decades in Parts of the Midwest
summary:
Parts of the Midwest have seen little to no sunshine for over a week in what has been one of the gloomiest January stretches in decades.
In Des Moines, Iowa, it's been one of the top three cloudiest Januaries in 70 years , according to the National Weather Service.
(Brian Brettschneider)Brettschneider also pointed out the cloudiest month of the year in the Great Lakes and upper Midwest tends to be either November or December, based on long-term statistics.
This is why areas downwind of the Great Lakes in winter are cloudier - and snowier - than other areas.
Last January, the coldest outbreak in at least two decades sent wind chills plummeting into the 50s and 60s below zero in the Midwest.

Dr. William Morice is the chair of the Mayo Clinic’s Department of Laboratory Medicine.
He says the clinic can produce 8,000 swab tests and 10,000 blood tests within a few weeks of getting the green light from state and public health officials.
The swab test checks for a diagnosis, while the blood test checks for antibodies, which would suggest the patient has recovered from coronavirus, perhaps without showing any symptoms.
He’s confident his team can produce 8,000 swab tests and 10,000 blood tests per day within the next few weeks.

A swath of snow over central and southern Minnesota led to numerous crashes during Monday evening's rush hour.
GOLDEN VALLEY, Minn. — A slow-moving snowstorm brought messy conditions to highways across the state on Monday afternoon and into the evening commute.

Minnesota State Patrol said there were 168 crashes statewide from 4 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. 18 of the crashes involved injuries.

title: 28 more flu-related deaths reported in MN
summary:
The number of flu-related deaths has reached 95 this season, matching last year's total.
ST PAUL, Minn. — The Minnesota Department of Health reported 28 flu-related deaths in the week ending Feb. 29, bringing the number of deaths to 95 this flu season.
Officials say 3,254 hospitalizations have been reported this flu season, which is already higher than last season's total of 2,543.
School outbreaks spiked by 43 in the reported week to bring the total number of outbreaks this season to 848.

title: Bernie Sanders to rally in Minnesota on eve of Super Tuesday
summary:
The Vermont senator and musical supporters Nathaniel Rateliff & the Nightsweats will stage a Get Out the Vote concert rally March 2 at St. Paul RiverCentre.
ST PAUL, Minn. — Current Democratic presidential frontrunner Bernie Sanders will come to Minnesota the night before Super Tuesday to rally with supporters in St. Paul.
The Sanders campaign announced that the Vermont senator and musical supporters Nathaniel Rateliff & the Nightsweats will stage a Get Out the Vote concert rally at St. Paul RiverCentre on Monday, March 2, starting at 7:30 p.m.
Doors will open at 5:30 p.m.Tickets are not required, but RSVPs are encouraged via the Bernie Sanders website.
Sanders comes to Minnesota on the heels of a caucus victory in Nevada and a series of solid debate performances.

title: Guilty plea in fatal shooting of 16-year-old in north Minneapolis
summary:
Andre Owens, 21, pleaded guilty to one count of second-degree murder and will be sentenced to 372 months in prison on Feb. 18.
MINNEAPOLIS — A Minneapolis man pleaded guilty on Monday to fatally shooting a 16-year-old last year in north Minneapolis.
The Hennepin County Attorney's Office announced on Wednesday that Andre Owens, 21, pleaded guilty to one count of second-degree murder and will be sentenced to 372 months in prison on Feb. 18.
On July 19, 2019, police were called to the area of Colfax Ave. North and 30th Ave. North where they found a 16-year-old male lying in the street with an apparent gunshot wound to his head, according to the complaint.
Owens was arrested on Aug. 15, 2019 after investigators were able to identify him as a suspect through video and witness reports.

title: How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
summary:
How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
Bring Me The NewsThe Twin Cities averages 54 inches of snow each winter, but 2019-20 appears to be on track to sprint past that annual average for a third consecutive winter.
That'll happen if the Twin Cities simply gets its average monthly snow totals the rest of the winter.
The average in February is 7.8 inches while March and April bring average snowfall totals of 10.2 inches and 2.5 inches, respectively.
We'll really go into the big time snow totals if this winter is similar to last winter, when 59.3 inches of snow fell February through April, including a ridiculous 39 inches last February.

title: Two gun bills clear MN House
summary:
One requires a criminal background check on all gun sales, the other would keep guns out of the hands of people proven dangerous to themselves or others.
ST PAUL, Minn. — State lawmakers took a big step forward in proposed gun reform legislation.
On Thursday night, the Minnesota House of Representatives approved two bills that supporters say represent significant gun reform: one requires a criminal background check on all gun sales; the other — the so-called red flag bill — would keep guns out of the hands of people proven dangerous to themselves or others, according to advocates.
Advocates weigh inMeantime, as lawmakers debated the measures, the Capitol filled with a crowd of orange-clad gun reform advocates.
The group greeted representatives as they showed up for the evening floor session and chanted their encouragement for the legislation.

title: MN legislators propose public transit changes
summary:
Democratic lawmakers are proposing legislation that would decriminalize transit fare evasion.
ST PAUL, Minnesota — Minnesota Democratic lawmakers are proposing a bill that they say would increase safety on public transit and make it more equitable.
The legislation would reduce the penalty for those caught riding public transit without paying from a misdemeanor to a petty misdemeanor, statewide.
The bill, if passed, would decriminalize fare evasion on public transit.
Rep. Tabke and Rep. Frank Hornstein, DFL-Minneapolis, are proposing that money from the fines go to support a Transit Ambassadors Program.

title: Minneapolis mayor: 'Core functions will continue' through coronavirus
summary:
Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey said the city's basic services will not be disrupted as preparations for coronavirus continueMINNEAPOLIS — During a half-hour news conference on Friday with the city's top leaders, Mayor Jacob Frey vowed that essential city services will not be disrupted as the state's largest city prepares for coronavirus.
"Let me reassure the public," Frey said, "that our core functions will continue without interruption."
Although he did not declare an emergency in the city, Frey made a number of notable announcements, including but not limited to:-- The city will not allow any water shut-offs for 30 days, regardless of a customer's ability to pay-- The mayor will be directly communicating with mortgage lenders and landlords to ask for "grace" on potential evictions-- Protections have been put in place to guard against cyberattacks-- IT tests are underway in the event that city staff would need to work from home-- The city has contingency plans for first responders and 911 dispatchers to ensure that emergency response is not impactedMayor Frey and Council President Lisa Bender also pledged support for small businesses, signaled that conversations have been happening with homeless and public housing advocates, and said that the city has a contingency plan in the event that any school closures become necessary (Minnesota has not recommended school closures yet).
Several other department heads also addressed coronavirus concerns, including Police Chief Medaria Arradondo and Fire Chief John Fruetel.
They said that plans are in place to protect first responders from potential exposure — and Arradondo said that masks are issued and used in accordance with public health recommendations.

title: Soggy September: Minnesota's record wet bias continues

The 41.39 inches of precipitation recorded is more than 10 inches above the running 30-year average annual precipitation of 30.61 inches.
The 9-months of 2019 so far the statewide average precipitation is 29.16 inches surpassing 1986 28.73 inches, as the wettest first 9-months of the year.

title: How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
summary:
How does this winter compare to last winter so far?

That'll happen if the Twin Cities simply gets its average monthly snow totals the rest of the winter.
The average in February is 7.8 inches while March and April bring average snowfall totals of 10.2 inches and 2.5 inches, respectively.
We'll really go into the big time snow totals if this winter is similar to last winter, when 59.3 inches of snow fell February through April, including a ridiculous 39 inches last February.

title: NOAA Releases 2019-2020 Winter Forecast: What Minnesota Will Get
summary:
MINNESOTA — Winter will be warmer than normal for some parts of the country this year, but not Minnesota.
We're likely for a wetter, snowier-than-average winter, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Climate Prediction Center.
"Wetter-than-average conditions are most likely in Alaska and Hawaii this winter, along with portions of the Northern Plains, Upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes and parts of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast," NOAA said in its 2019-2020 winter forecast, released Thursday.
"No part of the U.S. is favored to have below-average temperatures this winter."
We could see a roller coaster of temperatures this winter, as well.

title: Snow and blowing snow today

MINNEAPOLIS — The low pressure system winding it's way over the Great Lakes pulls cold air and moisture into eastern Minnesota and western Wisconsin, including the metro.
Snow is heaviest for the afternoon hours with winds picking up to create blowing and drifting as well.
Because of this, there is a Winter Weather Advisory for most of Minnesota and a Winter Storm Warning for western Wisconsin and extreme eastern central Minnesota in effect from midnight tonight through 12 a.m. Tuesday.
The advisory area can generally expect 1" to 4" of snow, whereas the higher amounts are forecast into Wisconsin for the warning area.

title: How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
summary:
How does this winter compare to last winter so far?
Bring Me The NewsThe Twin Cities averages 54 inches of snow each winter, but 2019-20 appears to be on track to sprint past that annual average for a third consecutive winter.
That'll happen if the Twin Cities simply gets its average monthly snow totals the rest of the winter.
The average in February is 7.8 inches while March and April bring average snowfall totals of 10.2 inches and 2.5 inches, respectively.
We'll really go into the big time snow totals if this winter is similar to last winter, when 59.3 inches of snow fell February through April, including a ridiculous 39 inches last February.

AccuWeather isn't the only organization that's released a 2019-20 winter prediction, but consensus can be hard to find when it comes to weather.

title: Town Hall Brewery’s 2019 Festivus
summary:
Festivus for the rest of us!
Town Hall Brewery will host its annual holiday gathering, on Tuesday, December 17 from 5-10 p.m. Join us for cup of complimentary mulled wine or spiked hot cider around our roaring outdoor bonfire and the traditional unadorned aluminum Festivus pole.
Air your grievances for $1, which includes one spin of the prize wheel.
Town Hall donates the money to Fairview Riverside Children’s Hospital, and with each spin of the wheel guests get a chance to win prizes including Town Hall products and merchandise.

title: Freehouse winter domes allow you to sit on the patio all winter
summary:
The Blue Plate restaurants have had a stroke of genius: Winter patio dining.
The Freehouse in Minneapolis has opened a series of "winter domes" that allow guests to eat on the patio all winter long.
The domes are on the patio but DiMuzio said they are still "cozy and warm."
"So I think it’s proving that people are looking for other things to do in the winter months."
DiMuzio said the Longfellow Grill in Minneapolis, another Blue Plate-owned restaurant, is also planning to open winter domes this season.

summary:

title: Police investigating 2 shootings in Minneapolis
summary:
Both shootings took place Sunday night.
MINNEAPOLIS — Police are investigating two shootings that occurred Sunday night in Minneapolis.
The first shooting was reported on the 400 block of Queen Avenue, near the Bryann Mar neighborhood around 6:00 p.m.A victim was transported to the North Memorial Medical Center.
No information has yet been released on the victim’s condition.
The second shooting occurred in the 2000 block of Hillside Avenue around 8:50 p.m.Officers confirm that a woman was shot in the foot, and was not seriously injured.

title: Minnesota rally Tuesday to support President Trump's impeachment
summary:
ST PAUL, Minn. — Tuesday evening, people will gather at the Minnesota State Capitol to call for the impeachment of President Donald Trump, and his removal from office.
It's one of hundreds of similar rallies happening across the country.
Tuesday, the House will vote on the rules for floor debate about impeachment.
Then, Wednesday, the full House will vote on two articles of impeachment, abuse of power, and obstruction of justice.
If passed, the Senate will hold a trial to determine whether or not President Trump is removed from office.

summary:

Accumulating snow is possible across the Plains and western Minnesota late this week and this weekend.

title: Here are the new Minnesota laws that are now in effect
summary:
Three new state laws that went into effect on Jan. 1.
Three new laws will go into effect in Minnesota on Jan. 1, 2020.
The state House of Representatives has released a list of the laws, which will impact tooth, tusk and horn traders, pharmacy benefit managers and opioid prescribers.
Pharmacy benefit managers will have requirements in network adequacy, ownership interest and transparency.
Continuing education need for controlled substance prescribersMuch of the state's response to the opioid crisis was included in a law that took effect July 1.

title: Delta waives change fees, MnDOT preparing as winter storm targets Minnesota
summary:
Delta Air Lines says it's waiving change fees for travelers flying to or from the Twin Cities this weekend as a major winter storm takes aim at the Upper Midwest.
Delta said Friday that it won't charge passengers who want to change their plans for flights on Saturday or Sunday.
If travelers don't change their plans, the airline advised them to check their flight status often through the weekend.
For drivers, the Minnesota Department of Transportation said it's monitoring the potential for freezing rain and snow.
MnDOT said travel in parts of western Minnesota and the Dakotas this weekend may be very difficult or perhaps impossible if gusty winds cause whiteout conditions.
